Ken,

My response consists primarily of clarifying questions, depending on =
the
answer I may or may not go back on the offensive :)

On Sat, Apr 2, 201=
1 at 5:17 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:

>
>
> Daniel, I apprecia=
te very much you sharing your thoughts. We were hoping to
> provoke just su=
ch discussion with this paper and your questions highlight
> important issu=
es. Let me try to respond below...
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > F=
rom: Kenneth Stanley [mailto:kstanley@...]
> > Sent: Saturday, Apr=
il 02, 2011 2:57 AM
> > To: 'Kenneth Stanley'
> > Subject: todelete2
> >
> =
> Ken,
> >
> > First off, I'll say that what I take as the central point, t=
hat EAs can
> > miss
> > critical intermediate objectives because they are =
awkwardly placed on the
> > fitness landscape, is a good one. However, I ha=
ve some concerns about the
> > experimental design in this paper:
> >
> > (=
1) You appear to be manipulating two variables at once. (a) whether the
> >=
 EA
> > has an objective and (b) whether there is a human in the loop. Sure=
ly you
> > have to pick only one at a time and control for everything else,=
 right?
> >
>
> It's only a problem if you believe that somehow a human wou=
ld do better at
> evolving to these objectives, which of course humans woul=
d not. Good luck to
> anyone who wants to re-evolve the skull from scratch =
again. It will never
> happen. Nor will anyone evolve any reasonably comple=
x *preconceived* picture
> from scratch no matter where it came from, wheth=
er once evolved in the past
> or not.
>


Ok, interesting.  I think I have =
misjudged the scope of the experiment.  I
assumed you were trying to *prove=
* something significant about the fact that
GAs can't evolve the solutions =
produced in picbreeder.  This was the basis
for my primary objection (3).  =
But you admit that the IGA won't evolve those
specific images either, with =
or without an objective.  Instead, you're just
trying to persuade the reade=
r of a suspicion based on just how bad the
performance is.  So really this =
paper would fall more under the category of
"evidence-based musings", is th=
at fair?



>
> On the other hand if you want to see non-objective search w=
ithout a human
> in the loop, that's what we've been doing with novelty sea=
rch, so there is
> plenty of literature on that combination at this point. =
You can find a lot
> here:
>
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/noveltysearch/usersp=
age/
>

>
> Let me suggest to you or anyone who remains a skeptic (which is=
 perfectly
> reasonable) to check out my talk on the topic (recorded in vid=
eo), which
> lays out the ideas much more broadly. It's only 70 minutes and=
 I think you
> will find it worth the time to see how I try to defend this
=
> counter-intuitive position, if nothing else to stimulate some thinking ev=
en
> if you still feel skeptical:
>
> http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Se=
arching-Without-Objectives
>


I haven't seen your talk on novelty search, =
I'll take a look at this.



>
> > (2) Furthermore, if it's IGA v. GA and '=
interestingness' is the
> evaluation
> > criteria, that ain't a fair fight.=
 Why should I believe there is more to
> > it
> > than that?
> >
>
> But in=
terestingness wasn't the evaluation criteria. This paper played by
> the tr=
aditional ground rules to whose defense you are now jumping. The
> objectiv=
e was definitively the skull (or the butterfly, or the eye..), not
> "inter=
estingness." The fact that the results come out so abysmally and leave
> yo=
u wanting to argue about interestingness just shows how unreasonable
> pedd=
ling these objectives as meaningful benchmarks can be. That's the whole
> p=
oint - the paper is a play on the traditional algorithmic evaluation scheme=

> that leaves the reader squirming, as it should.
>
> In fact, if you real=
ly think that IGA vs. GA isn't a "fair fight" when we
> are aiming for inte=
restingness, then you are in part in agreement (though
> inadvertently) wit=
h the spirit of our message. That is, if you are really
> convinced that IG=
A is so far superior to GAs at doing something interesting
> that it isn't =
even fair to contrast them, then unless we are somehow
> intentionally tryi=
ng to avoid evolving anything interesting, what are we
> doing wasting our =
time with objective GAs? Does it not highlight a central
> paradox in our p=
osition that we might actually care more about being "fair"
> than being "i=
nteresting?" Why are we even running these algorithms?
>


There's a differ=
ence between objectively and subjectively interesting.  The
former includes=
 the conventional optimization domains (e.g. travelling
salesmen) and the l=
atter include things like evolutionary art and music.  Is
this branch of yo=
ur research only concerned with the latter type of problem
(at least curren=
tly)?



>
>
> > (3) How do we know that intermediate objectives are in any=
 way
> significant
> > to discovering interesting pictures in Picbreeder? I=
 have a sneaking
> > suspicion that totally random search, followed by focu=
sed objective based
> > search when something 'pops' might be just as effec=
tive, and that the
> > 'intermediate objectives', while certainly necessary=
 to find a particular
> > image, are not very helpful in general to finding=
 interesting images. If
> > so, this is no chink in the armor of objective =
based search. I suppose
> > without intermediate objectives there can be no=
 exaptation, but does that
> > matter? What percentage of evolved features =
in biological organisms have
> > any exaptation at all in their history?
> =
>
>
> When you say the random search followed by objective-based search wou=
ld be
> "just as effective," I don't really understand: just as effective a=
t what?
> At doing something "interesting?" At achieving a specific objecti=
ve? Surely
> you don't believe that random search will produce images as in=
teresting as
> Picbreeder? The stepping stones (i.e. intermediate objective=
s) in Picbreeder
> are in effect fundamental discoveries of important regul=
arities that are
> later elaborated. For example, this simple face-like ste=
pping stone leads to
> a whole family of subsequent faces:
>
> http://picbr=
eeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D542
>
> Here you can get a family-tre=
e expansion from that individual:
> http://picbreeder.org/search/familytree=
.php?sid=3D542
>
> If you are willing to skip bridges like that because the=
y are intermediate,
> you would never find any of the treasures on the othe=
r side of the bridge.
> If you look back in the lineages of almost any inte=
resting image on the site
> you will find a similar story wherein fundament=
al regularities that were
> later exploited were first discovered in a diff=
erent context.
>


This point seems to beg for some controls for bias.  Wou=
ld we not expect
users to choose interesting pictures to start from most of=
ten?  And then
shouldn't we be unsurprised when most of the new interesting=
 images have
these in their lineages?  And shouldn't we be least surprised =
of all that
they share fundamental regularities with these ancestors?

Comp=
licating this even further is the fact that small genotypic changes in
picb=
reeder genomes create significant divergence in phenotype (correct me if
I'=
m wrong).  So a varied set of interesting pictures can readily proliferate
=
a short evolutionary distance away from a single ancestor, which exaggerate=
s
the representation of interesting pictures of the type you describe.



>=

>
> Just compare figure 6 and figure 7 in the paper to see how horrible it=
 is
> to start from a random place and then lock in on an objective (figure=
 7). It
> takes 29,000 generations to do the same thing it took 12 to do be=
tter.
>

>
> > (4) Finally - and this is the big one - one of the deadly si=
ns of Science
> > is
> > claiming a result as the objective a posteriori, a=
 point which eludes
> even
> > some very famous scientists. It's what allow=
s publications like this,
> > which
> > 'prove' psychic phenomena by mining=
 data for 'statistically significant'
> > results. The problem is, a result=
 isn't significant unless you were
> > specifically attempting to confirm i=
t when the experiment was designed
> > (i.e.
> > always follow up explorato=
ry experiment with a confirmatory experiment!).
> > I
> > heartily endorse =
exploring for/marvelling at results you weren't
> initially
> > looking for=
, but one should never use such results as the basis for any
> > sort
> > o=
f comparison. In the case of the eye experiment, who cares if the GA
> > co=
uldn't evolve the eye? The IGA can't either, and the fact that it
> > alrea=
dy
> > did is immaterial! I could be persuaded that the IGA is better at
> =
evolving
> > interesting images, but I do not believe it's any better at ev=
olving the
> > 'eye' (or 'dolphin', or 'apple'). In fact, I would bet that'=
s it's worse
> > at
> > evolving those specific images, intermediate object=
ives notwithstanding.
> >
>
> Should we really believe your statement? : "I=
 heartily endorse exploring
> for/marvelling at results you weren't initial=
ly looking for, but one should
> never use such results as the basis for an=
y sort of comparison."
>
> Is not our entire infatuation with evolution, th=
e very reason we choose to
> explore it as an algorithm, for the very reaso=
n that you say we should never
> use such comparisons? After all, natural e=
volution is just such a gallery of
> "results you weren't initially looking=
 for" yet it is the core inspiration
> for all our hopes and dreams for the=
 field and the example against which
> many of us compare our algorithms. T=
hus I strongly disagree with the
> principle you want to impose that marvel=
s attained without explicit a priori
> intent are outside of the realm of s=
cientific interest.
>


No, not out of the realm of scientific interest!  J=
ust out of the realm of
naive scientific experimentation (unless, as I susp=
ect is the case here, you
are reporting the results because they are *inter=
esting*, not because they
prove anything).  Note that I am not using 'naive=
' perjoratively, just
pointing out that this problem that you've decided to=
 tackle will require
exceedingly clever experimental design if you want to =
prove something.




> On the contrary, in fact the point of the paper is t=
hat our mistake is
> precisely that we have been misled by such a restricti=
ve and dogmatic
> doctrine. It is time that we did begin to contemplate the=
 marvel of what is
> discovered a posteriori. Asking why such amazing disco=
veries as human beings
> happens in nature is nothing like entertaining psy=
chic phenomena.
>


Just as an aside, I was not suggesting that it was.  Th=
e fact that the paper
I cited was about 'psi' was incidental, it was just t=
he most
fresh-in-my-mind example of a mistake I thought you were making.


=

>
> Imagine if we had left out the part about Picbreeder and simply run so=
me
> experiments to see if NEAT can evolve a set of pictures. After it fail=
ed
> miserably every time, following the traditional interpretation, we wou=
ld
> conclude that NEAT cannot evolve such pictures, or even pictures *like=
*
> them. The fact that Picbreeder did evolve many such pictures is thus
> =
relevant and scientifically interesting; it shows why the traditional
> imp=
lications we draw from such "failures" are far too expansive.
>
> You say t=
hat you could be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving
> interesting=
 images yet then you say that you don't think it is better at
> evolving th=
e eye. Yet the whole point is that it is better at evolving
> interesting i=
mages. Beware of missing the forest for the trees: It is not
> important wh=
ether the IGA is good at evolving the eye (or dolphin, or
> apple); it is i=
mportant that it is good at evolving images *like* those.
> There is no oth=
er algorithm on Earth that can do that. That is, there is no
> other approa=
ch that we know of that could get NEAT to actually encode images
> *like* c=
ars and butterflies in a CPPN. That fact should be startling to us,
> not d=
ismissed as a mere curiosity.
>



Ok, I mostly agree with this, but I must=
 reiterate my discomfort with the
fact that the experiment does not disenta=
ngle the "interactive" and
"objective-driven" variables.  Without doing so,=
 how are we to know what is
really doing the heavy lifting of creating thes=
e interesting pictures?




>
>
> > Anyway, though I have a lot of doubts a=
bout this particular paper, I
> really
> > appreciate these sorts of resear=
ch directions. Keep up the good work!
> >
>
> Sure, I understand. A good ha=
rd defense of the status quo is healthy to
> ensure that no one gets away w=
ith taking unjustifiable potshots :) Yet at
> the same time, questioning th=
e status quo is sometimes important if progress
> is to be made.
>


Agreed=
.



>
>
> Regards,
>
> ken
>
>  
>

--90e6ba3fcdcb41372d049ff7c064

It&=

<div style=3D"background-color:#fff"><div><div><div><br>
<br>
Let m=
e suggest to you or anyone who remains a skeptic (which is perfectly reason=
able) to check out my talk on the topic (recorded in video), which lays out=

l find it worth the time to see how I try to defend this counter-intuitive =
position, if nothing else to stimulate some thinking even if you still feel=
 skeptical:<br>

hing-Without-Objectives" target=3D"_blank">http://www.infoq.com/presentatio=
ns/Searching-Without-Objectives</a></div></div></div></div></blockquote><di=
v><br></div><div><br></div>


<div>I haven't seen your talk on novelty =
search, I'll take a look at this.</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><b=
lockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px =
#ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">


<div style=3D"background-color:#fff"><div><=
div><div><div><br>
<br>
> (2) Furthermore, if it's IGA v. GA and &#3=
9;interestingness' is the evaluation<br>
> criteria, that ain't =
a fair fight.  Why should I believe there is more to<br>
> it<br>
> t=
han that?<br>
> <br>
<br></div>
But interestingness wasn't the evalu=
ation criteria.  This paper played by the traditional ground rules to whose=
 defense you are now jumping.  The objective was definitively the skull (or=
 the butterfly, or the eye..), not "interestingness."  The fact t=
hat the results come out so abysmally and leave you wanting to argue about =
interestingness just shows how unreasonable peddling these objectives as me=
aningful benchmarks can be.  That's the whole point - the paper is a pl=
ay on the traditional algorithmic evaluation scheme that leaves the reader =
squirming, as it should.  <br>



<br>
In fact, if you really think that IG=
A vs. GA isn't a "fair fight" when we are aiming for interest=
ingness, then you are in part in agreement (though inadvertently) with the =
spirit of our message.  That is, if you are really convinced that IGA is so=
 far superior to GAs at doing something interesting that it isn't even =
fair to contrast them, then unless we are somehow intentionally trying to a=
void evolving anything interesting, what are we doing wasting our time with=
 objective GAs?  Does it not highlight a central paradox in our position th=
at we might actually care more about being "fair" than being &quo=
t;interesting?"  Why are we even running these algorithms?</div>


</d=
iv></div></div></blockquote><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>There's =
a difference between objectively and subjectively interesting. =A0The forme=
r includes the conventional optimization domains (e.g. travelling salesmen)=
 and the latter include things like evolutionary art and music. =A0Is this =
branch of your research only concerned with the latter type of problem (at =
least currently)?</div>


<div><br></div><div>=A0</div><blockquote class=3D=
"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding=
-left:1ex"><div style=3D"background-color:#fff"><div><div><div><div><br>
<b=
r>
> (3) How do we know that intermediate objectives are in any way sign=
ificant<br>
> to discovering interesting pictures in Picbreeder?  I have=
 a sneaking<br>
> suspicion that totally random search, followed by focu=
sed objective based<br>
> search when something 'pops' might be =
just as effective, and that the<br>
> 'intermediate objectives',=
 while certainly necessary to find a particular<br>
> image, are not ver=
y helpful in general to finding interesting images.  If<br>
> so, this i=
s no chink in the armor of objective based search.  I suppose<br>
> with=
out intermediate objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that<br>
&=
gt; matter?  What percentage of evolved features in biological organisms ha=
ve<br>
> any exaptation at all in their history?<br>
> <br>
<br></div=
>
When you say the random search followed by objective-based search would b=
e "just as effective," I don't really understand: just as eff=
ective at what?  At doing something "interesting?"  At achieving =
a specific objective?  Surely you don't believe that random search will=
 produce images as interesting as Picbreeder?  The stepping stones (i.e. in=
termediate objectives) in Picbreeder are in effect fundamental discoveries =
of important regularities that are later elaborated.  For example, this sim=
ple face-like stepping stone leads to a whole family of subsequent faces:<b=
r>



<br>
<a href=3D"http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D542=
" target=3D"_blank">http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D542</=
a><br>
<br>
Here you can get a family-tree expansion from that individual: =
<br>
<a href=3D"http://picbreeder.org/search/familytree.php?sid=3D542" targ=
et=3D"_blank">http://picbreeder.org/search/familytree.php?sid=3D542</a><br>=

<br>
If you are willing to skip bridges like that because they are interme=
diate, you would never find any of the treasures on the other side of the b=
ridge.  If you look back in the lineages of almost any interesting image on=
 the site you will find a similar story wherein fundamental regularities th=
at were later exploited were first discovered in a different context. </div=
>


</div></div></div></blockquote><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>This =
point seems to beg for some controls for bias. =A0Would we not expect users=
 to choose interesting pictures to start from most often? =A0And then shoul=
dn't we be unsurprised when most of the new interesting images have the=
se in their lineages? =A0And shouldn't we be least surprised of all tha=
t they share fundamental regularities with these ancestors?</div>


<div><b=
r></div><div>Complicating this even further is the fact that small genotypi=
c changes in picbreeder genomes create significant divergence in phenotype =
(correct me if I'm wrong). =A0So a varied set of interesting pictures c=
an readily proliferate a short evolutionary distance away from a single anc=
estor, which exaggerates the representation of interesting pictures of the =
type you describe.</div>

>
Just compare figure 6 and figure 7 in the paper to see how horrible it is=
 to start from a random place and then lock in on an objective (figure 7). =
 It takes 29,000 generations to do the same thing it took 12 to do better.<=
/div>

 comparison.  In the case of the eye experiment, who cares if the GA<br>

Should we really believ=
e your statement? : "I heartily endorse exploring for/marvelling at re=
sults you weren't initially looking for, but one should never use such =
results as the basis for any sort of comparison."<br>



<br>
Is not o=
ur entire infatuation with evolution, the very reason we choose to explore =
it as an algorithm, for the very reason that you say we should never use su=
ch comparisons?  After all, natural evolution is just such a gallery of &qu=
ot;results you weren't initially looking for" yet it is the core i=
nspiration for all our hopes and dreams for the field and the example again=

riori intent are outside of the realm of scientific interest. </div>

v></div></div></blockquote><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>No, not out o=
f the realm of scientific interest! =A0Just out of the realm of naive scien=

t pointing out that this problem that you've decided to tackle will req=
uire exceedingly clever experimental design if you want to prove something.=

<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>=A0</div><blockquote class=3D"g=

<div><br></div><div>=A0</di=
v><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:=
1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex"><div style=3D"background-color:#fff"><div>=
<div><div>
<br>
Imagine if we had left out the part about Picbreeder and si=
mply run some experiments to see if NEAT can evolve a set of pictures.  Aft=
er it failed miserably every time, following the traditional interpretation=
, we would conclude that NEAT cannot evolve such pictures, or even pictures=
 *like* them.  The fact that Picbreeder did evolve many such pictures is th=
us relevant and scientifically interesting; it shows why the traditional im=
plications we draw from such "failures" are far too expansive.<br=
>



<br>
You say that you could be persuaded that the IGA is better at evo=
lving interesting images yet then you say that you don't think it is be=
tter at evolving the eye.  Yet the whole point is that it is better at evol=
ving interesting images.  Beware of missing the forest for the trees:  It i=
s not important whether the IGA is good at evolving the eye (or dolphin, or=
 apple); it is important that it is good at evolving images *like* those.  =
There is no other algorithm on Earth that can do that.  That is, there is n=
o other approach that we know of that could get NEAT to actually encode ima=
ges *like* cars and butterflies in a CPPN.  That fact should be startling t=
o us, not dismissed as a mere curiosity. </div>


</div></div></div></block=
quote><div><br></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Ok, I mostly agree =
with this, but I must reiterate my discomfort with the fact that the experi=
ment does not disentangle the "interactive" and "objective-d=
riven" variables. =A0Without doing so, how are we to know what is real=
ly doing the heavy lifting of creating these interesting pictures?</div>
